MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - County Limerick Factory Closure.

Speaker.P: I am pleased that I have been allowed to raise an issue that is causing a great deal of concern in my constituency. As the Minister is aware, Kantoher Food Products Ltd., of Killeedy, Ballaugh, County Limerick, which has an annual turnover of £14 million was wound up and a liquidator appointed to the company by the High Court. The company employ 130 full-time employees and provide a vital industrial lifeline to the people in the surrounding areas.

The area surrounding Kantoher has a strong dependence on agriculture and this is the most important industrial employer in an area stretching from Tournafulla to Dromcollogher where they draw most of their employees within that catchment area. The liquidator has allowed the company to trade and they are now catering for a boom Christmas trade. The plant was established back in the twenties and the technology used in the processing of chickens and turkeys is one of the most modern in the country.

MainHeading.P: It is most important for the company to continue to operate and for the liquidator, Mr. John Hyland of accountants Ernst & Young, to engage in discussions with potential clients whose ambition is to continue with the processing of turkeys and chickens in this area. The area received a body blow recently when Kantoher co-operative was taken over and a rationalisation followed with up to 40 jobs being lost. Should anything happen to this plant it would be devastating to the local economy. Many of the workers have firm roots in the area and have taken out mortgage commitments, etc. The likelihood of other suitable jobs being found would be unlikely. Over 40 poultry producers who have shown good faith with this project over the years would also be affected by the present discussions on Kantoher poultry products future. Many of these have borrowed heavily for the provision of broiler houses.

I appeal to the Minister to use all the support of both his office and the Industrial Development Authority to back the liquidator in ensuring that this company are enabled to continue in business for the future.

I would like to compliment the management and workers for the work they have put into this company and I sincerely believe that the high level of skilled workers will be an asset to any suitable employer who is interested in this project and will continue to operate it on an ongoing basis.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh) Minister of State at the Department of Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.P: At the outset, may I thank Deputy Finucane for raising this matter in the House and I am glad to have the opportunity to reply to this question on the liquidation of Kantoher Food Products Ltd.

I share the Deputy's concern at this unfortunate development. It is always sad to see any company getting into difficulties resulting in the appointment of a liquidator. It is particularly so in the case of a company such as Kantoher Food Products Ltd., which had such worth-while ambitions for the poultry meat sector.

MainHeading.P: Kantoher Food Products Ltd., a wholly-owned subsidiary of Kantoher co-operative, were formed in August 1988 to take over and develop the poultry activities of the co-operative, that is poultry processing, hatchery, egg laying and egg purchasing and processing.

The new company embarked on a modernisation programme to upgrade and expand the poultry facilities and by the end of 1990 had a 10 per cent share of the poultry market with an employment level of about 130. However, it is understood that the company ran into financial difficulties necessitating the appointment of a liquidator. In this regard the Deputy will appreciate that the decision to appoint a liquidator at Kantoher Food Products Ltd. is one over which the Minister for Agriculture and Food has no control.

The liquidation is, as I have said, very regrettable, and one's sympathy must certainly go out to the employees who may lose their jobs. I am also concerned about the poultry producers who supply the company. However, I understand that the liquidator is trading for a short period and there is the possibility that the business and assets may be sold as a going concern thus preserving some if not all of the jobs at the factory and continuing outlets for the breeders.

While the Kantoher situation is unfortunate, I would like to say that the poultry industry generally is in a sound state. The industry has been expanding and now has a farm-gate value of some £130 million which translates into retail values of about £350 million. The value of poultry and egg exports in 1990 amounted to £34.5 million. Including Kantoher there are 16 poultry slaughterhouses approved to EC standards with a throughput of about 40 million broilers per annum. I am confident that the industry has the basic structure to enable it to maintain and develop its position in the EC and world markets and expand employment.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Shared Home Ownership Scheme.

Speaker.P: I am grateful to you, a Cheann Comhairle, for giving me the opportunity to raise this important matter.

MainHeading.P: The shared home ownership scheme announced in February last during the much-vaunted press conference by the then former Minister for the Environment advertising his plan for social housing has turned out to be a cruel confidence trick for hundreds of desperate housing applicants.

The shared ownership scheme is essentially a fraud. People who meet the low income requirement of the scheme and who have no chance of public housing — because of the virtual termination of the public housing programme — have been disgracefully misled by the Government in the context of this scheme. They have been invited to apply for accommodation under the terms of the scheme and the public and this House have been invited to believe that the scheme would make a significant contribution to the housing crisis. In fact, at the end of 1991, not a single house in the greater Dublin area has been purchased under the scheme. I am advised that in the State as a whole two such purchases have been effected.

The disgrace is not due to any foot-dragging on the part of local authorities. It is solely due to the inherent defects in the scheme itself. A prospective purchaser under the scheme would need to be either an incurable optimist or a fool. How could any Deputy of any party advise a constituent, driven by a desire to get housing for his or her family, to enter into the following kind of deal?

I take as an example the typical house that would attract a £1,000 deposit under the terms of the scheme for fees and so on and that would require the following mortgage-rental repayments on the 50 per cent purchased, with the obligation to buy out the remaining 50 per cent equity at the end of, or during, the 25 years. In the case of a house costing £41,000, the monthly outgoings in the first year would be as follows if one were buying a 50 per cent share from the start. The cost of a 50 per cent share would be £20,500 funded by a deposit of £1,000 and a mortgage loan of £19,500. Mortgage repayments on the £20,500 loan would be £199 a month. The rental repayments multiplied by 5 per cent would equal £85 a month, making total repayments of £284 per month. For a person on an income necessarily less than £12,000 per annum repayments of £284 monthly represent a very hefty commitment.

However, that is not all. After 25 years the person concerned owns only half of a house and must then buy out the 50 per cent unpurchased equity. In the example I have given above the unfortunate occupier would then be faced with a cost of £52,500 to buy out the remaining unpurchased equity, that is the original outstanding £20,500 at an escalator of 4 per cent per annum over 25 years. Can one imagine a 40 year old person on a low income making hefty repayments over 25 years then being hit with a bill for £52,500 at the age of 65 to buy out the second half of his or her house? Is it any wonder that not a single purchaser has been found in the greater Dublin area?

In those circumstances, how is one to find the unpurchased equity? The Department of the Environment refuse to advise local authorities what will happen if people cannot find the money to buy out the unpurchased equity at the end of the 25 years. No bank would give a loan to a 65 year old person on a small pension. Further, the Minister for the Environment has failed to put in place the legislation necessary to enable local authorities to implement the scheme as a single transaction. As it now stands the scheme — bankrupt, misleading and fraudulent as it is—is inoperable because a local authority must first purchase the house, keep it on the council stocks until the council meet and then sell it on to the purchaser. This practice is unwieldy and unworkable and I ask the Minister to reply tonight to this specific point as well as to indicate whether he intends to address the substantial defects in the scheme itself.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Connolly) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Connolly)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Connolly)
Speaker.P: Criticism of the shared ownership system is entirely ill conceived. It is wrong to criticise the system for not meeting objectives it was never intended to meet.

MainHeading.P: Shared ownership is one, and only one, of a wide range of options designed to meet social needs in a reasonable and well targeted way over the coming years. These options include the provision of local authority housing, whether by new building, the acquisition of existing houses or by way of vacancies in the existing local authority rented housing stock.

Speaker.P: A Cheann Comhairle, I hate to interrupt the Minister, but the issue on the Adjournment debate is the shared ownership scheme.
The Deputy had his opportunity.

In addition, the provision of voluntary housing is being expanded substantially by virtue of the voluntary housing capital grant schemes and the new rental subsidy scheme. The mortgage allowance for tenants will allow those tenants who can afford to do so to acquire private housing for their own accommodation thereby freeing up local authority housing for re-letting to persons on the waiting lists. The new sites scheme will assist low income households to provide their own housing, either cooperatively or individually.
With respect, a Cheann Comhairle, we are not talking about social housing; we are talking about the shared ownership scheme.
Deputy Rabbitte, it is unfair to interrupt. There is a very rigid time limit of five minutes.
I want to point out that this year we will have catered for accommodation needs——
A Cheann Comhairle——
No one interrupted you, Deputy, and I want you to accord the same courtesy to the Minister of State.
He is reading the wrong script.
I do not have the wrong script.
Deputy Rabbitte, please desist.
The Minister is reading the wrong script. This is not the shared ownership scheme.
The Deputy is being very disorderly and very unfair in interrupting the Minister so often in a five minute reply.
But I asked your permission to raise the subject of the shared ownership scheme. The Minister is not talking about the shared ownership scheme.

If the Deputy is dissatisfied with the reply of the Minister of State, he has many other ways of approaching this issue. He may not interrupt in this fashion. Eroding the precious time available to the Minister is unfair. Deputy Rabbitte was not interrupted.
I accept that, a Cheann Comhairle, but this is not the point I raised.
Please, Deputy.

Overall, I estimate that the Government will have catered for the accommodation needs of about 5,500 households in 1991. Next year will be the first full year of operation of the range of new measures introduced in the plan for social housing and the number should increase to about 7,000. The shared ownership scheme will make a significant contribution to that.

MainHeading.P: Shared ownership is designed to help persons on lower incomes to achieve home ownership in stages. It has attracted a high level of interest. Local authorities are responsible for administering the system and have been authorised to deal with 1,000 shared ownership transactions under a pilot programme. Up to the end of September last, the latest date for which I have figures, 760 applications had been received, 59 approvals have issued and two transactions were completed.

Last May local authorities were authorised to proceed with the selection of prospective owners under the pilot programme. While the full operation of the shared ownership system requires new legislation, the system may be operated on the basis of interim arrangements devised by my Department with the benefit of expert legal advice. These arrangements allow the purchaser to occupy the house on foot of a letting agreement which will be converted to a formal shared ownership lease with retrospective effect as soon as the legislation is passed. Local authorities have been asked to operate the system on this basis and to process applications for shared ownership as quickly as they can.
I am fully satisfied that the interim arrangements provide an effective basis to allow shared ownership transactions under the pilot programme to proceed in advance of the legislation.

I also assure the House that the Housing Bill will be published early in the next Dáil session and that the House will then have a very good debate on that Bill. All of these issues can be brought up and I shall discuss them in the House.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - National Sports Stadium.

Speaker.P: A Cheann Comhairle, I thank you for affording me the opportunity of raising this matter. I wish to give half a minute or so to Deputy Deenihan.
Is that satisfactory? Agreed.
The recent decision by FIFA that World Cup matches would be all-seated affairs, highlights once again the need for a national all-seater stadium.

During the recent European and World Cup tournaments tens of thousands of Irish supporters travelled throughout the length and breadth of Europe supporting the Irish team. Not only were they super supporters, they were in fact excellent ambassadors of this country. It now transpires that most of these fans, many of whom followed the Irish team for over 20 years, will not gain access to home games in the forthcoming World Cup tournaments. The current prediction is that Lansdowne Road, where the matches will be played, can only accommodate 23,000 seated.

I am reliably informed that up to last week, 120,000 block booking applications had already been received by the FAI for these matches. I hope that a mechanism can be devised whereby the real supporters, those who supported the Irish team for years when it was not popular to do so, can be accommodated.

This scandalous position obtains because of the total inaction by this Government and the Minister of State with responsibility for sport in particular. It is not as if they were unaware of the increased safety consciousness of FIFA and the various European governments, which was obvious in the aftermath of the Heysel Stadium tragedy. Some three years ago the Minister made headlines when he announced he had proposals to make Croke Park into a super all-seater stadium. The recent decision by the GAA to refuse permission for a joint Gaelic/Soccer attraction at the RDS would indicate that this proposal was always a non-starter. The Minister should have been aware of this and come up with alternative proposals.

There are alternatives, locations such as the North Wall area, Grangegorman, Phoenix Park and Santry Stadium which have been mentioned over the years. All of these had certain advantages. If the Minister was serious about a national sports stadium proposals should have emerged by now.

MainHeading.P: The national lottery which was originally established to provide facilities for sport, recreation and youth has been an outstanding financial success. The sporting public demand to know why some of this money has not been used to provide a national sports stadium.

I listened during the week to a contribution on radio by a real sports supporter, somebody who follows all modes of sport. He commented that, at the triumphant homecoming of the Irish soccer team from the World Cup, politicians vied with each other to gain access to the victory bus. That supporter had a point when he said: “Some two years later what have these fair weather supporters secured for the sportsmen and women of this country?” Is it not a scandal that young people must go abroad to achieve their full sporting potential because of lack of basic training facilities here?”

Given that a new stadium with a seating capacity of 40,000 would cost in the region of £35 million to £40 million, I suggest there would be merit in a joint public-private sporting organisation venture which would not necessarily exclude Lansdowne Road. Sport here needs a Minister aware of the problems, who is prepared to fight his corner for the necessary finance to resolve them. I call on the Minister this evening to put his proposals to this House and sporting people in general.

Speaker.P: As Deputy Ryan said, the original purpose of the national lottery was to provide a national stadium. However, the Government hi-jacked the national lottery using those moneys in a confetti-like fashion, totally ignoring the genuine aspirations of our sporting public. If one looks at the Book of Estimates one will see millions of pounds of that money being allocated to normal Government spending here. That is the way in which national lottery funding has been used.

MainHeading.P: Following the World Cup in July 1990 the Minister stated in the course of a radio interview on “This Week,” that he would establish a special expert committee to examine the posibility of providing a national outdoor stadium, which he later denied in this House. If the Minister did establish that committee would he say whether they ever reported or made recommendations? Would the Minister inform us this evening whether they did and, if so, what were their recommendations? But I must say that at present the Minister has frustrated all of the sporting fraternity and they are most annoyed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Education (Mr. F. Fahey) Frank Fahey
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Education (Mr. F. Fahey)
Speaker.P: I am glad of the opportunity to respond to this debate. Indeed, I thank Deputy Ryan for having raised the issue. Let me say at the outset that I too want to see a national outdoor stadium developed. Indeed, much work has gone into efforts to endeavour to bring that about. I might go through those efforts briefly but before so doing it is most important for all of us to understand that the country needs only one major crowd-capacity stadium.

The main difficulty we have encountered in recent years is that we have had three sporting organisations all wanting their own stadium, the GAA in Croke Park wanting to develop that stadium, the IRFU wanting to develop Lansdowne Road and the FAI from time to time wanting to do different things but it is fair to say they would like to see their own 40,000 seater stadium, as the Deputy mentioned. What we do not need here is a 30,000-seater stand costing in the region of £40 million which would be filled on only two or three occasions in the year. That is our major dilemma with regard to the national stadium. I am not prepared to countenance the development of three stadia here, funded by the State in the first instance, but which would also have to be funded by each individual sporting organisation. That would be a total waste of money——
We agree.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: A total waste of money which rather should be used in the development of the games of soccer, rugby, hurling or football throughout the country. We all know that every club, whether it be a hurling, soccer, football or rugby club, needs to put money into the promotion of the game among children. We are not prepared to go along with the develpment of three stadia, putting massive amounts of money into bricks and mortar. The point is that we want to build or develop one. But I have found that, unfortunately, the three organisations cannot, or are not prepared, to come together to build one or to utilise one of the existing ones.

Yes, we tried with regard to Croke Park. The GAA — and I respect their stand on this — decided that they did not want Croke Park shared as a national stadium. We tried also to develop Morton Stadium and had got initial support and agreement from the FAI who subsequently changed their minds. We have also examined the possibility of a national outdoor stadium on the green-field site.
Green fields out in Tallaght and a good roads network.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: I am quite happy to consider that proposal. I appreciate the sincerity of both Deputies who contributed here this evening but we do not need another 40,000-seater stadium. As any Member will know, what we need is a 75,000 seater minimum because, whether it be an all-Ireland, rugby international or a soccer international, any fewer than 75,000 tickets is not sufficient. Therefore, another 40,000-seater stadium, while just about serving the interests of soccer, in my view, would not constitute the proper end result.
Soccer and rugby if the GAA will not go along.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: But the IRFU are not interested. The problem with the GAA in that respect is that they have said to me: yes, we are interested in principle in becoming involved in this proposal but, at the same time, they are saying: we also want money to develop Croke Park.

I will be very straight and fair about this, I have to accept part of the blame on the part of the Government that perhaps we have not been as forthcoming as we might have been with very significant amounts of money. Nonetheless I must say also that, unless and until the three sporting organisations look forward rather than back, we shall not have a national outdoor stadium here.

If the three national organisations are prepared to put their heads together and develop a national stadium either on a green field site or in one of the existing stadia with a capacity for 75,000 people, I am quite satisfied that I would have a good case to take back to Government, asking them to support such a venture and that they would respond favourably. Otherwise, we are only fooling around with three organisations endeavouring to develop their own stadia which they will then fill on no more than two or three occasions annually. That amounts to waste of money and I am not prepared to involve this Government in that kind of wastage. We have met the three organisations and have tried to make progress but we were simply unable to do so.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Education and Defence Matters.

Speaker.P: In the mid-eighties the Department of Education approved an extension of four permanent classrooms and a general purposes room for Naomh Erc primary school, Kilmoyley, County Kerry. In December 1988, following a meeting between the board of management, the local Oireachtas representatives and the former Minister for Education, Deputy O'Rourke, it was agreed that a modified proposal would be acceptable to the Department of Education and to the board of management. This proposal included the replacement of the existing prefab with two classrooms and extensive restoration work to the existing building which would include two further classrooms, an office, a kitchen and a library. Unfortunately this proposal will still leave the school without a general purposes room. The board of management in their frustration had no option but to accept this compromise.

The prefab was provided in 1967 and is about to disintegrate. In January 1990 a window was blown in during a period of strong winds. This could recur at any time. Over 25 pupils, junior and senior infants, use the prefab as a classroom. It is totally unsuitable for these young children. I am not exaggerating. The officials of the Office of Public Works, and Dr. Lucas and Dr. Jackson of the Southern Health Board have agreed that the prefab and the existing school building are substandard.

All the preparatory work has been done and the necessary documentation is with the Department. I ask the Minister to allow the project go to tender immediately and ensure that financial provision is made for the extension in 1992.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: I am glad Deputy Deenihan has given me the opportunity to make the position of the above school clear to the House and also to the parents and pupils of Glenderry, County Kerry. The provision of an extension of two classrooms and a general purposes room has been approved.

However, due to a changed financial climate and the demands on the capital for national schools it was not possible to advance the above extension. Added to the above considerations, the number of pupils attending the school and future enrolments have shown a marked decline. The numbers have decreased from 172 enrolments in 1989 to 136 enrolments in September 1991. The school has five teachers in five classrooms. Due to the fact that some of the classrooms are on the small side an extension of a classroom has been approved, together with a staff room and a library-medical room. This scheme is at sketch scheme planning stage.

MainHeading.P: I would not consider this a priority case as there are sufficient classrooms for the school. However, when the sketch scheme is completed a decision will be taken on the way forward, bearing in mind the demands on available capital together with the numbers of other projects on hands. The chairman of the board of management will then be consulted and given advice on the necessary steps by my Department.
This is down the priority list. A number of schools in Kerry have been improved in recent years. I take the point the Deputy makes and will look at the matter again.

Speaker.P: I wish to raise the serious situation in relation to the condition of Adare girls' national school in County Limerick. Adare is known nationally as a beautiful village but the conditions under which the teachers and pupils have to operate in Adare can only be described as primitive. The school was founded in 1850. There are four classrooms and a spare room. The spare room is used by the remedial teacher and also as a staff room.

The rooms are small and there is a high noise level due to the type of partitions and the structure. There is no fire exit in the school and any fire chief would consider its condition totally unsatisfactory and a fire hazard. The outside toilets are primitive, have a galvanised roof and the toilets do not flush on occasions. Those unsatisfactory conditions have attracted rats.

There is serious overcrowding in the classrooms. I raised this issue with the Minister on 4 December last. The cost of the extension and reconstruction has been estimated at £100,000. A dynamic parents committee raised school contributions over 15 per cent of the estimated cost. Planning permission has been approved and the Office of Public Works and the Department of Education have approved the project. It was anticipated that the project would go to tender last year, but this did not materialise. The pupils and the parents anxiously await the Minister's approval for this project to go to tender.

MainHeading.P: I trust the Minister will recognise the primitive school that exists in Ireland's prettiest village, take appropriate action and approve this project for tender. I look forward to the Minister's reply.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: I accept the point the Deputy made in regard to Adare. It is a priority case and is ready to go to tender. The Deputy will be aware that discussions with the Department of Finance in regard to next year's budget have just been completed with the announcement of the Estimates today. I have not yet had the opportunity of examining the allocation for primary school buildings next year. Bearing in mind that there are a number of school projects at a similar stage to the Adare project, that there are a number of school boards of management vying for the limited amount of resources which will be available next year and that each board of management makes the case that their school is deserving of special consideration, the onus falls on me to ensure that each case receives due consideration.

I assure the Deputy that every consideration will be given to allowing the Adare girls' primary school to go to tender next year, if at all possible. I accept the very fair case the Deputy has continually made in respect of this school and the need to provide permanent walled divisions between classrooms, as well as modern facilities and adequate fire safety standards in keeping with the stringent legislation laid down by the authorities for the safety of pupils in national schools. I accept the urgency of this case and I assure the Deputy that I will do everything possible to get the job out to tender in the coming year.

I welcome the opportunity to highlight a problem of grave concern to parents, teachers and pupils in regard to the national school at Kinvara. The Sisters of Mercy first came to Kinvara in 1879 and set up a girls' school. In 1904 it was re-roofed and in 1970 the then boys' school in Kinvara was amalgamated with the girls' school on this site. One prefab building was purchased then and a second about seven years ago.

MainHeading.P: Unfortunately the latter was secondhand, in very bad condition and there are very serious problems with it now. The school has 180 pupils and six teachers. A campaign has been going on since 1987 to have an extension built and refurbishment of the old building carried out.

I visited the school recently at the request of the parents and was shocked by what I saw. The roofs of the prefabs leak very badly on wet days. Water running down the walls makes it too dangerous to use light switches. There are holes in the floor large enough for a child to fall into. Children of both sexes are using the same toilets.

The parents consider the condition of the school to be a serious health hazard. Planning permission for the refurbishment and extension has been sought and received by the manager. Even the children have written to the Minister requesting that the work proceed. I tabled a parliamentary question on this matter on 3 December and was told that the question of the invitation of tenders would be considered in the context of the 1992 budgetary situation. The Minister went on to say that he was not in a position to say when building work would commence.

I should like to ask the Minister of State, who represents the same constituency, if he will use his influence to ensure that tender documents are accepted and provision is made for this school in the 1992 budget. The Minister of State availed of an opportunity in the Connacht Tribune last week to respond to my invitation to outline what he was doing in regard to this school. However, in that very good contribution he forgot to say what he has been doing since 1987. He suddenly got very interested in the matter when I raised it in the Dáil. I welcome his response and ask him to state when building works will commence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: I am delighted to have the opportunity to inform Deputy McCormack that since 1987 I have been trying to clear up the mess left in Galway by him and his party——
I was not there in 1987.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: I did not interrupt the Deputy. The same did not happen in the constituencies of other members of his party. Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey

Speaker.P: The Deputy should not give me that crap that he was not here.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey

That was five years ago.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: The file states that the question of providing a new school or an extension——
The Minister, like the GAA, should be looking forward and not backwards.
No interruptions, please.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. F. Fahey Mr. F. Fahey
Speaker.P: It states that the question of providing a new school or an extension was discussed by the school authorities, the Office of Public Works and the Department. No firm decision or action was taken. That was the position from 1983 to 1987. From 1987 to 1990 nobody from Kinvara approached me even though I am the TD for the area and live eight miles down the road. I was approached by the principal of the school in March 1990 to have the project reactivated. We had to start from the beginning. The Department's architectural staff visited the school in April 1990. We concluded the planning in April 1991 and sent the sketch plans to the parish priest for planning permission. It is a pity they did not——
I regard interruptions on a very limited debate of this kind comprising of five minutes as very unfair and disorderly.

On 27 November 1991 a circular was issued from the headquarters of the Southern Command FCA's Sars-field Barracks, Limerick to the OC of each unit in the Southern Command FCA to implement a 25 per cent reduction in the Permanent Defence Force cadre. Unit commanders were advised to immediately initiate the selection process as it was envisaged that the reduction should take place before 1 January 1992. Unit commanders were asked to have their recommendations ready by 13 December.

I understand that this circular was later put on hold. However, it now seems that it will be implemented as originally planned. This will mean the number of Permanent Defence Force personnel attached to the FCA in County Kerry will be reduced by nine. These individuals will probably have to return to Limerick or Cork barracks. It will lead to major upheavals for their families who will suffer not only a loss of income but major family disruption. The net effect will be a further reduction in the effectiveness of the FCA in County Kerry. It will also affect the morale of the force, the quality of the training, the organisation of manoeuvres and so on. The presence of fewer professionals will lead to a decrease in standards.

This reduction in the Permanent Defence Force cadre has given rise to a fear among the FCA that it is Government policy to disband the FCA. This would be a tragedy not only from the point of view of Defence but would be a further blow to rural Ireland. Rather than weakening the Permanent Defence Force and the FCA in County Kerry the Minister should be strengthening the Defence Forces presence in the county for a number of reasons. Tralee Barracks should also be utilised more by the Defence Forces particularly as a training centre.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Defence (Mr. D. Ahern) Minister of State at the Department of Defence (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Defence (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: I thank the Deputy for raising this issue as it gives me the opportunity to outline the actual position in regard to this circular.

MainHeading.P: There are no proposals to reduce the rates of allowance payable to members of the Permanent Defence Force assigned on a full-time basis to FCA units. As the Minister explained to this House in the Adjournment Debate on Thursday last, 12 December, the report of the Commission on Remuneration and Conditions of Service in the Defence Forces highlighted the need for an extensive examination of the present deployment of the Defence Forces and, in this context, the rationalisation of FCA units is being considered.

There are over 900 members of the Permanent Defence Force assigned to the FCA on a full-time basis where they are employed on administrative and training duties. The cost of their pay and allowances amounts to some £16 million per annum. The military authorities have in recent months carried out an examination of how the training and administration of the FCA might be performed on a more cost-effective basis, resulting in more involvement by FCA members in the running of the organisation.

While I can understand that the Permanent Defence Forces personnel assigned to the FCA might be concerned at these developments, I would again point out that there will be no loss of employment for any of them. I would also like to take this opportunity to assure the House that full consideration will be given to the domestic or other difficulties raised by Deputy Deenihan that may arise for individual members of the Permanent Defence Forces by being transferred from their existing locations. Personnel who may be transferred to fill other appointments in the Permanent Defence Forces will, of course, be eligible to receive removal expenses in accordance with Defence Forces regulations.

The cost of the pay and allowances of the Permanent Defence Forces personnel assigned to the FCA is substantial and, in these times of budgetary constraints, it is particularly important to ensure that the most efficient use is made of the resources that are available. While most of the administrative duties will continue to be carried out by Permanent Defence Forces personnel, there will be greater emphasis in the future on the role of FCA personnel in the running of the organisation. In this regard I am satisfied that the members of the FCA will be equal to the task and that the training and administration of the organisation will continue to be performed to the standards necessary for the force to discharge their role.

I am conscious of the necessity to maintain and improve An Forsa Cosanta áitiúil as a viable component of the Defence Forces and I am concerned that the resources available to us should be utilised to the most beneficial effect for that purpose.
The Dáil adjourned at 11.30 p.m. until 10.30 a.m. on Wednesday, 18 December 1991.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - IFA Report.

Qst.Quest: if he has received the report produced by the IFA, which claims that middlemen in the pork and bacon business have been taking excessive profits at the expense of farmers and consumers; if his attention has been drawn to the fact that the report claims that prices paid to farmers are back down to the level of ten years ago, although the price of some pigmeat products in the shops has doubled in the same period; if he will take any actions as a result of this report; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: A copy of the report referred to has been received by me.
The position is that there is no price control in operation in the pigmeat sector. However I understand that the IFA have met the Director of Consumer Affairs and that he is considering the report.

There is also provision under the recently introduced Competition Act, 1991 for the IFA, if they feel aggrieved, to take action against any party engaged in anti-competitive practices, e.g. price fixing or cartel arrangements, prohibited by the Act.

MainHeading.P: Producer prices in Ireland were somewhat depressed between June and August this year but since then have started to recover and are now higher than those obtaining this time last year. Having regard to the latest EC forecast which estimates that pig supplies within the Community will fall by nearly 5 per cent in the period up to July 1992, it is expected that producer prices both here and in the rest of the EC will be maintained during this period above earlier levels. This improving situation, combined with existing favourable feed costs, should restore producer confidence and ensure that the current expansion in the national pig herd will continue.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Dr. Woods)

MainHeading.P: As indicated to this House on 13 November in response to a question from Deputy Hilliard, and as I also indicated on Friday last here, a major effort is underway to conclude the Uruguay Round negotiations by the end of this year or early next year. The Director General of the GATT, Mr. Dunkel, has announced that he will produce a Draft Final Act covering all areas including agriculture on 20 December. His aim will be to reach an overall agreement based on these texts as quickly as possible thereafter.

The agriculture negotiations have been dominated by the differences in the negotiating approaches of the EC and US. The House will recall that the Community's agriculture offer agreed by Ministers in November of last year provides for a 30 per cent reduction in overall support over ten years from 1986, based on an aggregate measurement of support together with subsidiary commitments on border measures and on export supports. The US, which is in a position largely shared by the Cairns Group, has been seeking a 75 per cent cut in support and protection for agriculture over ten years with a 90 per cent in export subsidies.

Following high level contacts between the EC and the US in the Hague in early November, both sides have been meeting regularly to seek to resolve outstanding differences. While some progress has been made, major political issues remain unresolved. The extent and effect of any concessions that the Community might make will depend on how these remaining differences are resolved. Any agreement would of course also have to meet the requirements of the other parties in the GATT.

The GATT negotiations have now entered a very crucial stage. My aim during the coming weeks will be to ensure the Community's global approach is maintained and that whatever commitments are entered into in the areas of internal support, market protection and export competition are internally coherent and fit into this approach. This is essential to the maintenance of an effective and operational Common Agricultural Policy. It follows that I would have major difficulties with any restrictions on export subsidies which are not coherent with the support mechanisms generally or with import arrangements which did not provide for adequate Community preference. These are obviously critical points for Ireland. It is also essential that credit is obtained for past reform measures and that whatever arrangements are agreed for agriculture must also be accepted as compatible with GATT rules. In other words, any agreement must in practice recognise the legitimacy of the Community's support system.

The scope of the measures to be disciplined has yet to be resolved. The Community's approach is that the compensatory payments such as those proposed under the Common Agricultural Policy reform as well as the disadvantaged areas payments and other socio-structural measures should not be subject to discipline under GATT. It should be possible to develop appropriate criteria to ensure that payments related to production control and protection of the environment as well as under regional assistance programmes can be exempted from reduction commitments.

It has been evident since the GATT negotiations commenced that the outcome would result in reduced support and protection levels for agriculture in the Community and in the other participating countries. Ireland's priorities in the negotiations have always been to ensure that whatever commitments are entered into will not prevent the Community from continuing to operate support measures to the benefit of the Irish agricultural and food sector and the wider economy. We also have sought to ensure that the more stable trading conditions and trade opportunities which will flow from a satisfactory GATT outcome will be at least as beneficial to the Irish agriculture and food sector as to that in any other country.

When the Community's GATT offer was being finalised in November 1990 we secured firm agreement that account would be taken of the particularly difficult situation of certain categories of producers and regions and that the total level of assistance to the less favoured regions should not be reduced as a result of the implementation of the outcome of the GATT negotiations. The House can be assured that I will be pursuing those issues with the utmost vigour.

Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself with the uniformity of application of the Abattoirs Act, 1988.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The Abattoirs Act, 1988 provides for the annual licensing of abattoris by a central authority, the Department of Agriculture and Food, in order to ensure uniformity of standards throughout the country and to maintain these standards on a continuous basis. Arrangements have been made to ensure that the provisions of the Act are applied uniformly. These include annual inspection and licensing.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Food Industry Job Losses.

Qst.Quest: if he will give details of (1) the investigation his Department have conducted to determine the loss of jobs in the Irish food industry if the proposed reform of the Common Agricultural Policy goes ahead; (2) the cost to the economy of these jobs losses and (3) the action he proposes to take both at home and abroad to alleviate these effects; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: Analysis of Common Agricultural Policy reform carried out within my Department indicates that, if the current Commission proposals were to be adopted unchanged, decreases in output at farm level could be of the order of 2 per cent for cattle, 3 per cent for milk and 8 per cent for the cereals sector. This could lead to a reduction of up to 10 per cent in the farm income level in one full year post-reform. The establishment of a direct relationship between these changes and employment in the food sector is highly problematic. In any event in the course of negotiations on these reforms I will seek to obtain full redress for any negative effect on output, income and jobs.

Furthermore I intend to prepare and put into effect an integrated programme for the development of the agri-food sector once the reform of the Common Agricultural Policy and the current GATT negotiations are completed. It is my intention that this programme will address, among other things, the development of value-added in the industry backed up by a vigorous marketing strategy to achieve a consumer oriented food sector which will make the most of Ireland's natural advantages.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Passenger Vessel Licensing.

Qst.Quest: the plans he has, if any, to licence boats with fewer than 12 passengers; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Mr. Wilson) John P. Wilson
Speaker.P: As Minister with overall responsibility for safety of life at sea, I have for some time been anxious to have legislation enacted which would enhance the regulation of the safety of passenger vessels plying our waters.

The Merchant Shipping Acts, which are administered by my Department, apply to vessels which carry more than 12 passengers to sea or on rivers, canals, lakes or estuaries. Such vessels are required to hold a valid passenger certificate and are subject to annual surveys conducted by the marine surveyors of the Department.

Vessels which carry 12 passengers or fewer for hire or reward are outside the scope of the Merchant Shipping Acts but may be licensed by local authorities under the Public Health Acts. However, the token level of fines under these Acts and the absence of any statutory safety requirements in respect of such vessels has resulted in the legislation being less than effective.

For some time, therefore, I have been anxious to update the legislation on vessel safety so as to reflect modern realities. The Merchant Shipping Bill, 1991 which was circulated to Deputies on 3 December 1991 will: bring vessels carrying 12 or fewer passengers for reward, passenger boats, within the scope of the Merchant Shipping Acts for the first time. Following inspection of a vessel for suitability for use as a passenger boat and for compliance with safety regulations, if any, made by the Minister for the Marine, a licence may be granted for a period of up to two years; update the level of penalties in the existing legislation for all passenger vessels; and give the Minister for the Marine powers to make regulations governing the safety of fishing vessels, pleasure craft and other craft and their crews and occupants.

MainHeading.P: I am in the process of setting up safety working groups to review safety procedures and standards on Irish vessels in the fishing vessel, pleasure craft, small ferry and other sectors and to advise me on measures that might be taken to improve safety, both under regulations and through non-statutory means.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Relations with USSR.

Qst.Quest: if, in view of the changes which have taken place to date within the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and which are continuing, he will outline the exact status of our relations with the USSR and the various republics of that Union which have declared their total independence; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Collins) Gerard Collins
Speaker.P: Ireland currently continues to recognise and to have diplomatic relations with the USSR. Following the restoration of their independence, we have recognised, and established diplomatic relations with Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia.

On 8 December, the Russian Federation, Ukraine and Belorus agreed to establish a new Commonwealth of Independent States open to other Republics that wished to join. Discussions between the Republics on the Commonwealth, its institutional structures, and its membership are continuing. The Commonwealth's international status is not yet clear.

Ireland's response to these developments is being co-ordinated with its partners in the Twelve. On 10 December the European Council at Maastricht expressed the desire of the Twelve “to open with the Republics comprising the Commonwealth, in a spirit of co-operation, a dialogue regarding the development of their mutual relationship”.

MainHeading.P: It is the Government's policy to develop relations with the Republics that have declared independence. We have established direct contact with the administrations in many Republics and our embassy in Moscow is maintaining liaison with them.

I hope that the Twelve will be able to adopt a common position on all aspects of relations with the Ukraine, including the question of recognition.
I would refer the Deputy to the reply which I gave to Deputy Jim O`Keeffe on 11 December concerning Ireland's attitude to the Ukraine following the recent referendum there.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Company Service Contract.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline (1) all the factors taken into account by his Department in reaching the decision of August 1990, that a contract for service exists between a lending company (details supplied) and its agents and (2) the reason, prior to this decision being reached, his Department instructed this company to make PRSI-PAYE deductions from the earnings of a person (details supplied) in County Waterford; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: I have been advised by the Revenue Commissioners that the key question to be answered in deciding the issue was whether the relationship between the company and its agents was an employer-employee one or whether the agents acted as self-employed individuals providing a service for the employer. The Revenue Commissioners decided on the basis of the terms of the agreement between the company and the agents that the latter applied and that the contract was that of a contract for service. The factors which influenced the decision were: the level of supervision and control by the company over the agents did not correspond with the existence of an employer-employee relationship; the method of payment and treatment of expenses suggested that the agents were self-employed; the company had no sanction against the agents apart from termination of the agreement which was available to both parties; the usual employee rights were absent i.e. pension, holidays, sick pay etc.; and the agents were not restricted to doing business with the company.

MainHeading.P: As regards the second part of the Deputy's question at the time that PAYE was deducted there was a perception that an employer-employee relationship existed.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Clothing Import Taxes.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the controls if any, which exist on persons from outside this country bringing clothing into the country for sale to the public in such places as hotels; and if these persons are liable to pay taxes, such as VAT, prior to their departure from the country.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: Persons who import clothing into the State are liable for VAT on importation at 12.5 per cent in respect of adults clothing. Childrens' clothing is zero-rated.

In certain circumstances, the importation of clothing originating in some non-EC countries is prohibited except on production to Customs of a valid import document/authorisation issued by the Department of Industry and Commerce. In addition persons engaged in occasional trading in places like hotels must obtain an occasional trading permit from the Minister for Industry and Commerce.

MainHeading.P: Persons who sell clothing of any description in the State are obliged to register and account for VAT where annual receipts from such sales exceed £32,000. Activities of the type mentioned by the Deputy are kept under review by the Revenue Commissioners to ensure compliance with the VAT requirements. As recently as Sunday, 8 December, investigations on some of these sales disclosed that the persons concerned were registered for VAT and had paid VAT at point of import on the goods being offered for sale.

MainHeading.RHead: of Married Women in Civil Service
MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Reinstatement of Married Women in Civil Service.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: if a married woman (details supplied) who was forced to resign from the Civil Service due to the marriage embargo in 1977 will be reinstated in the Civil Service as a result of a recent court case.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: No woman has been obliged to resign on marriage since the passing of the Civil Service (Employment of Married Women) Act, 1973.

Section 11 of the Civil Service Regulation Act, 1956 (as amended) provides for the reinstatement of women in certain circumstances, namely if she was a civil servant, retired from the Civil Service for the purposes of, on or following marriage, and

... is for the time being a widow or a woman who did not get married or in respect of whom it is established to the satisfaction of the Minister for Finance that she is not being supported by her husband.

The provisions governing reinstatement were challenged by the Employment Equality Agency and the matter was referred to an equality officer of the Labour Relations Commission, whose report issued recently. As provided in the Employment Equality Act, 1977, I have lodged an appeal with the Labour Court against the findings and recommendations of the equality officer.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Privatisation Liabilities Guarantee.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline (1) the reason for Government approval for a guarantee in respect of any liabilities arising from the privatisation of Comhlucht Siúicre Éireann Teoranta, (2) the date when this guarantee was approved and (3) the amount of the financial undertaking involved; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: It is assumed that the Deputy is referring to certain warranties and indemnities given in connection with the flotation of Greencore plc.

At the time of and in order to facilitate the flotation of Greencore plc., an agreement was entered into between the Minister for Finance (as the then owner of all the issued shares in that company and in its predecessor company, Irish Sugar) and Greencore and its directors whereby certain warranties and indemnities were given by the Minister to Greencore and by Greencore to the Minister and the directors. In essence the effect of that agreement, dated 9 April 1991, was that certain legal obligations, responsibilities and liabilities to the underwriters of the flotation and to prospective investors in Greencore would be shared between Greencore and the Minister in the proportions in which the funds raised by the share offer were received by them respectively. The responsibility, obligations and liabilities covered by such agreement essentially relate to assurances that the flotation in the manner proposed was within the legal powers and authorities of the Minister and of Greencore and its directors and that the terms of the listing particulars or prospectus on the basis of which the shares were being sold was in compliance with legal and stock exchange regulations.

Such agreements are a common feature of flotations on the Stock Exchange. If the Minister and Greencore had not been prepared to give indemnities and warranties, the flotation of Greencore could not have proceeded.

MainHeading.P: There is no question of the Minister having any actual liability under that agreement in the absence of its being established in court that the Minister was in breach of the agreement or that the facts were otherwise than as warranted. In the event that such a claim was successfully established in the courts the amount of the liability would have to be determined by the court having regard to the actual facts of the case and the extent, if any, of the attributable loss of the plaintiff in any such action. The Minister has not received and would not at this point in time anticipate receiving any notification of any such claim.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Tax Evasion by Landlords.

Qst.Quest: if, in view of the allegation of widespread tax evasion by landlords in the private semi-furnished rented sector, he will give a small tax allowance to private sector tenants, with a view to establishing an effective register of all landlords; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. B. Ahern) Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: I have no plans to introduce an allowance as proposed by the Deputy. Apart from tax policy and potential cost considerations, the Revenue Commissioners are of the view that the giving of such an allowance would not greatly enhance their ability to deal with evasion by landlords, particularly taking into account the level of revenue resources which would have to be committed to operate it.

However, the commissioners recognise the potential for evasion that exists in this sector and are already operating an extensive programme to tackle such evasion. A register of known landlords is maintained by Revenue and this is supplemented by details of multiple habitation obtained from the local authorities as well as the register of electors. The commissioners also have wide powers to obtain details of landlords from both tenants and letting agents. Finally, information is received from members of the public in certain circumstances.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Live Cattle Trade With Libya.

Qst.Quest: when the live cattle trade with Libya is due to recommence; and if he will estimate the number of cattle involved.
when the live cattle trade to Libya will recommence; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 117 and 154 together.

MainHeading.P: As the Deputies are aware, extensive consultations have taken place at official and diplomatic levels with the Libyan authorities. In September 1990, my predecessor visited Libya with officials following which a Libyan delegation visited Ireland in late November 1990. While they indicated that they would make a favourable report to their authorities regarding the health status of cattle and beef in Ireland and there have been a series of contacts with the authorities since then, Libya has not yet moved to resume imports of live animals from Ireland. This is partly because of local Libyan difficulties in the animal health area. However, contacts between the Irish and Libyan authorities are continuing and I am hopeful that as a result the live cattle trade will resume shortly, and in time return at least to pre-1990 export levels of 30,000 cattle per annum.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline (1) the criteria which will be operated by his Department in determining the appeals on the extension and reclassification which were made to the disadvantaged areas scheme and (2) the way in which this criteria will compare with the criteria used in the last extension and reclassification; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: In order to be considered for inclusion in the disadvantaged areas — less severely handicapped scheme — an area must be homogenous and meet all five of the following criteria: 1, less than 7.8 per cent ploughed land; 2, less than one livestock unit per forage hectare; 3, less than 80 per cent of the national average family farm income per male farm worker; 4, population density less than 27 per square kilometre, and 5, more than 30 per cent of the working population engaged in farming.
The criteria, which were laid down by the EC Commission, were used in the recent extension and will remain unchanged when determining the areas under appeal.

The criteria used for the more severely handicapped areas were the same except in the case of 3 and 5 where the percentages were 40 per cent and 40 per cent respectively. In line with the commitment in the Programme for Economic and Social Progress, my Department are at present reviewing both of these criteria to enable the case of marginal areas under appeal to be considered in association with the appeals panel.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Fair Trade Commission Report.

Qst.Quest: if he has studied the report of the Fair Trade Commission special review; if he intends to make any change as a result of his examination; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. O'Malley)
Speaker.P: I take it that the Deputy is referring to the report by the Fair Trade Commission of their review of the Restrictive Practices (Groceries) Order, 1987. The report was published on 13 December 1991.

The majority review of the commission was that the groceries order should be revoked as the main provisions of the order would be superseded by the Competition Act, and that the ban on below-cost selling under the order constitutes a serious interference in the market place and should, therefore, be revoked.

In view of the fact that the Competition Act has only recently come into force and in order to give interested parties an opportunity to study the report I have decided to keep the question of retention of the Restrictive Practices (Groceries) Order, 1987 under review for the moment.

Section 5 of the Competition Act, 1991 prohibits the abuse of a dominant position in trade for any goods or services. Section 6 provides a right of action in the courts for any person aggrieved by such abuse. It is for the courts to decide on actions taken under section 6 of the Act.

Speaker.P: It is proposed to answer Questions Nos. 174 and 178 together.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Barrett Mr. S. Barrett
Qst.Quest: if he will arrange for the payment of a refund of PRSI to a person (details supplied) in County Dublin and if his attention has been drawn to the fact that the payment already made in this case to the person's employer is now under the control of the receiver appointed to the firm in question; whether there is an obligation on his Department to ensure that such payments are returned to the oversubscriber and not his/her employer; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Daly) Brendan Daly
Speaker.P: The employer in this case paid PRSI at an incorrect rate in respect of the person concerned. Accordingly, both the employer and employee were entitled to a refund of the PRSI contributions paid in error.

The regulations governing refunds provide that contributions paid in error by an employer on behalf of any person may be repaid to the employer on the receipt of an undertaking from such employer to pay to that person the amount due out of such repayment.

Accordingly, on the written undertaking of the employer in this case, a refund of £3,098.46, of which £951.51 was due to be paid to the person concerned, was made to the employer on 7 November 1991. The employee however, has since confirmed that he has not received his share of the refund.

It is understood that a receiver was appointed to the company involved on 12 November and my Department are investigating the matter with a view to establishing whether there is any possibility of obtaining a refund of the employee's portion of PRSI for the person concerned.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Means Tested Schemes.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: if he will outline (1) the schemes under the control of his Department which are based on means test, (2) the basis of the means test which applies to each scheme and (3) the level of income above which an applicant is deemed ineligible for the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Daly) Brendan Daly
Speaker.P: The schemes under the control of my Department which are means tested are: unemployment assistance; pre-retirement allowance; lone parent's allowance; deserted wife's allowance; prisoner's wife's allowance; widow's (non-contributory) pension; orphan's (non-contributory) pension; old age (non-contributory) pension; blind pension; rent allowance; supplementary welfare allowance; carer's allowance; single woman's allowance and family income supplement.

MainHeading.P: The legislative provisions governing means are contained in the Social Welfare (Consolidation) Act, 1981 and in regulations. The following are the main areas under which means are assessed: cash income; the yearly value of property owned but not personally used or enjoyed, such as capital or house property or land not personally used by the applicant; the yearly value of property used or enjoyed, such as a farm of business; the value of income or property of which the person has deprived him/herself in order to qualify for pension or assistance or payment at a higher rate and in the case of unemployment assistance, single woman's allowance and supplementary welfare allowance the value of free board and lodgings enjoyed by the applicant.

The current short term assistance rate is £50 and the long term assistance rate is £55. Single people with weekly means below these rates will qualify for payment provided they meet the general eligibility conditions.

While the means assessment criteria are broadly similar for all schemes there are nevertheless variations in the manner in which some of the components, principally capital and income from earnings are assessed. There are also different levels of disregards of means under the schemes.

The scheme is currently operating in up to 53 centres nationwide with a maximum of 1,060 places available.

The purpose of the VTOS is to encourage second chance education among the long term unemployed with a view to their return to the workforce. There are no plans at present to extend the scheme to other categories of recipient.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Welfare Schemes Anomaly.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that women who take up social employment schemes which are of tremendous benefit to their community, are not deemed dependants of their husbands for social welfare purposes but were so deemed prior to their starting on the scheme; if his attention has further been drawn to the following effects of this anomaly: (1) the spouse remaining at home loses an adult dependant rate on their social welfare claim, (2) they lose out on the 70 per cent Christmas bonus which they would otherwise be eligible to claim for their dependant and (3) they lose out on the free fuel allowance; and if he will outline his views on whether those on social employment schemes should be deemed dependants for social welfare purposes in order to make it more attractive for women to take up these schemes.

if he will confirm that the anomalies if any which exist whereby a married person taking up a social employment scheme loses out financially will be corrected in the forthcoming Social Welfare Bill; and if he will outline his views on the examples supplied (details supplied).

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Daly) Brendan Daly
Speaker.P: It is proposed to take Questions Nos. 187 and 188 together.

MainHeading.P: Under the legislation, the spouse of a social welfare claimant cannot be regarded as an adult dependant of the claimant where he or she is either in receipt of a social welfare payment in their own right or has weekly earnings from employment or self-employment in excess of a specified limit, currently £55 per week. Where a spouse has earnings, they must be taken into account in assessing the means of a claimant of unemployment assistance. If one spouse participates in a social employment scheme (SES), a portion of the SES earnings must be assessed against the other spouse's unemployment payment.

To treat earnings from a social employment scheme differently from earnings from other sources in assessing means for unemployment assistance purposes would raise questions of equity. I am, however, conscious of the need to facilitate and encourage participation in social employment schemes and I am examining this issue. Any change in present arrangements would have financial implications and could only be considered in a budgetary context.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Means Tested Schemes.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: if he will outline (1) the schemes under the control of his Department which are based on means test (2) the basis of the means test which applies to each scheme and (3) the level of income above which an applicant is deemed ineligible for the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.P: Applicants for services under the scheme of civil legal aid and advice are subject to a means test. The structure and operation of the means test under the scheme arises directly from the recommendations of the Pringle Committee in their report on civil legal aid, 1977.

The committee recommended that a special means test should be applied because of their central recommendation that the legal aid services should not be restricted to applicants who could afford to pay little or nothing for the cost of legal services, but should apply also to people who were better off and who could afford to contribute a reasonable proportion of that cost from their own resources. For that reason a means test based on disposable rather than gross income was recommended by the committee and the scheme provides accordingly. With effect from 17 January 1991 the income qualification limit for services under the scheme has been increased to £6,200 disposable income per annum.

MainHeading.P: With regard to the grant of criminal legal aid, the position is that this is entirely a matter for the courts under the provisions of the Criminal Justice (Legal Aid) Act, 1962. Legal aid may be granted only if the court is satisfied that the means of the person applying for it are insufficient to enable him to obtain legal aid at his own expense. The legislation does not prescribe eligibility standards and the review committee on Criminal Legal Aid, in their final report in 1981, recommended against the introduction of an eligibility ceiling or a means test for criminal legal aid, on the grounds that they involve a certain amount of inflexibility and are not appropriate to a scheme of criminal legal aid.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Hospital Waiting Lists.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if she will outline (1) details of waiting lists for hospital treatment classified by whatever categories that are made available to her by the reporting authorities at the last date on which they reported this information to her Department, (2) the state of waiting lists by health board area and (3) the state of waiting lists for the most important elective procedures.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: the estimated cost of eliminating all hospital public waiting lists for operations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions 230 and 231 together.

The Deputy will be aware that the Dublin Hospital Initiative Group, under the chairmanship of Professor David Kennedy, focused on the management and review of waiting lists and general strategies to improve waiting times for treatment. The group have indicated that the numbers recorded as being on waiting lists may significantly overstate the numbers of patients who are, in fact, awaiting treatment in the absence of regular validation to remove the names of patients who have been treated elsewhere, moved away or no longer require treatment.
I am determined to tackle the most pressing problems in this area. As a first step I intend to ensure that accurate, meaningful and readily accessible information is maintained by all agencies.
As I mentioned in the Dáil last week, the Kennedy group, in their recently published report, recommended that a number of important steps should be taken as follows:
—comprehensive, standardised information should be maintained and reviewed by each hospital concerning the numbers and types of patients awaiting admission;

MainHeading.P: —validation to establish meaningful waiting list data should be adopted as a firm policy in each hospital and that such policies ensure that appropriate management and clinical action is taken on foot of such reviews;
—hospitals should carry out bulk postal reviews of waiting lists where patients have been on waiting lists for more than an agreed period of time;

—hospitals should target waiting lists by ensuring that explicit account is taken of waiting times in scheduling admissions, including theatre lists, and that speciality teams have reasonable activity targets to guide their attempts to minimise waiting by patients.

The group have recently been re-convened and part of their new remit is to pursue the implementation of the recommendations in relation to waiting lists in the Dublin hospitals. In addition, health boards and hospitals authorities in the area outside of Dublin have been asked by my Department to consider the good practice recommendations contained in the report and to report back to my Department on their plans for the implementation of the recommendations, including those in relation to waiting lists.

My priority at this stage is to ensure that the validation process as outlined in the report of the Dublin Hospital Initiative Group is implemented on an on-going basis in all hospitals and I will be pursuing this vigorously with all the agencies concerned. I will be in touch with the Deputy as soon as progress has been made by the agencies on the validation process.
In the absence of comprehensive and reliable data, it is not possible to estimate accurately the cost of eliminating all public waiting lists.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Medical Card Means Test.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: the cost of extending the means test for eligibility for medical cards by 25 per cent.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I assume that the question refers to the effect of an increase of 25 per cent in the income guidelines which are used in the assessment of medical card eligibility.

There is no available income distribution data which would be sufficiently comprehensive and detailed to enable an estimate to be made of the number of additional people who would come within the income guidelines if they were increased by 25 per cent.

In any case, it must be appreciated that the income guidelines, while used in the assessment process, have no statutory basis and are not the essential criterion for determining full eligibility, i.e., entitlement to a medical card. The legislation provides that full eligibility shall be awarded to persons who, in the opinion of the chief executive officer of the relevant health board, are unable without undue hardship to arrange general practitioner medical and surgical services for themselves and their dependants. In practice the chief executive officers assume that all persons with income below the guidelines meet this criterion, so that further assessment of the medical and other circumstances of an applicant is necessary only where his or her income exceeds the guidelines. A person whose income exceeds the guidelines but who is found to satisfy the statutory criterion is awarded the medical card.
