Qst.Quest: if he will outline the plans, if any, he has to change the higher education grant scheme to make provision within it for a more lenient assessment of applicants who already have a brother or sister at university; and if he will further outline the estimated cost of setting off £3,000 of family income in respect of each child already in college when assessing the eligibility of a subsequent child.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the cost of extending eligibility for higher education grants to all mature students over 25 years of age, regardless of parental income.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Davern) Noel Davern
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 256, 257 and 260 together.
My Department are not in a position to provide an estimate of the cost of raising the income thresholds for the higher education grants scheme by 33 per cent.

Under the recently published joint Programme for Government it is proposed to amend the higher education grants scheme so that, inter alia, the income eligibility of a mature student not dependent on his/her parents would be determined by reference to his/her own income and, if married, that of his/her spouse.
The estimated cost of this proposal in a full year would be £0.20 million.

The Programme for Government also provides that income eligibility limits will be adjusted to take account of cases where more than one member of a family is attending a third level institution and proposals are being brought forward in this regard.
The estimated cost of the Deputy's proposal to lower the reckonable income of a family by £3,000 in respect of each dependent other than the first would be £4 million approximately in a full year.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the cost to the Exchequer of increasing the school leaving age by one year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister or Education (Mr. Davern) Minister or Education (Mr. Davern)
Speaker.P: The percentage participation of 16 year olds in full-time education has increased from 82 per cent in 1985-86 to over 90 per cent in 1989-90 and it is anticipated that it will continue to increase.

In the circumstances, the additional cost to the Exchequer of a formal raising to the school leaving age is difficult to estimate and will depend on the extent to which participation rates continue, in any event, to improve irrespective of the legal school leaving age.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Davern) Noel Davern
Speaker.P: With regard to (1) the schemes under the aegis of my Department are as follows: the higher education grants scheme; and the vocational education committees (VECs) scholarship scheme; (2) for a candidate to be eligible for the award of a higher education grant, the “reckonable income” of the candidate and of the candidates' parents or guardians must be within the income limits set out in the relevant scheme. For the purpose of the scheme “reckonable income” means gross income from all sources, less any sum paid by way of contribution to a superannuation fund, and excluding also children's allowances under the Social Welfare Acts, holiday earnings of the candidate and payments under the family income supplement scheme; (3) the level of income above which an applicant is deemed ineligible for a grant is a function of the number of dependent children in the family. For example an applicant for a grant in 1991-92 who comes from a family with three dependent children will qualify for a full maintenance grant if the family income does not exceed £11,595 per annum.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. V. Brady) Vincent Brady
Speaker.P: Section 103 of the Defence Act, 1954 provides that a member of the Permanent Defence Force shall not join, or be a member of, or subscribe to any political organisation or society.

Defence Force regulations made pursuant to section 103 of the Act provide that where a member of the Reserve Defence Force is called out on permanent service he shall not join, or be a member of or subscribe to or canvass or collect for any political organisation or society whatsoever. Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: if he will outline (1) the schemes under the control of his Department which are based on means test, (2) the basis of the means test which applies to each scheme and (3) the level of income above which an applicant is deemed ineligible for the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. V. Brady) Vincent Brady
Speaker.P: A means test is included in the scheme of special allowances for veterans of the War of Independence and allowances for spouses of deceased holders of the Service (1917-1921) Medal.

A special allowance is an annual sum of such amount as when added to the applicant's yearly means will not equal or exceed a prescribed sum. The current prescribed sums range from £1,694 to £1,737 a year depending on marital status and age of spouse.
Yearly means in this context include the means of the applicant's spouse. The value of assessable means is based on reports furnished by social welfare officers.
The means test for these allowances has been relaxed progressively over the years and is now far from severe. Social welfare benefits are largely disregarded or only partially assessed as means.

Awards of special allowances are made for a period of four years. During that period, the allowance is not reviewed by my Department regardless of any improvement in the applicant's means. However, the allowance holder is entitled to seek a revision of his allowance at any time during the currency of the award if his means have worsened, in which event his case would again be investigated by a social welfare officer.

A minimum figure of £185 per annum was determined in 1980 for persons who qualify on means for a special allowance. The current rate is £636. This is also the rate paid to spouses of deceased medal holders.
